Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story:
I stared at my phone, rereading her message: “Let’s pick a night this week for our date! I’m free any evening.” I smiled, picturing her excitement, and scrolled through my calendar. For once, my evenings were open too. I started to type a reply, but my laptop pinged—a Slack alert from work. My heart sank as I read the urgent message: “Production outage. Users locked out. Root cause: your module. Can you jump on a call ASAP?” 

My mind raced. I knew how much she valued our time together, especially after weeks of late nights and missed plans. She’d been patient, but I could sense her hope for a real evening with me. At the same time, the outage was critical. Customers were frustrated, and my team was counting on me to fix it fast. I felt the pressure from both sides, the weight of her expectations and my responsibility to my job. My fingers hovered over my phone and keyboard, torn between sending her a date suggestion or joining the emergency call. My chest tightened as I realized I couldn’t give both what they needed from me tonight.
